div.sent: We know that fruits develop from flowers.
Ripe mango, jackfruit, banana, orange etc. which may be eaten without cooking are considered to be fruits.
These fruits develop by transformation of ovaries of gynoecium of flower.
The transformation occurs in the ovary after pollination and fertilization.
In case pollination and fertilization do notoccur, immature, ovaries of flowers fall off and thus fruits do not develop.
From this discussion, it is evident that it is very difficult to define fruit in easy language.
The structure formed by fertilization of the fully grown mature ovary is known as fruit.
Pericarp: The outer covering of the fruit is known as pericarp.
The pericarp of a fleshy fruit like mango consists ofthree layers.
Epicarp: The outer most layer of mango is called epicarp.
The epicarp may be thick.
Mesocarp: This is the fleshy part of fruit.
The mesocarp is edible.
Endocarp: This is the innermost layer of pericarp and it covers the seed.
Seeds: One or more seeds may be present inside a fruit.
But in mango a single seed remains covered with the endocarp.
A mango seed is dicotyledonous (a seed which consists of two cotoylodons).
Types of fruits: Fruits are classified on the basis of their origin, nature, source, fertilization etc.
Fruits are primarily divided into two groups on the basis of the floral parts, which contribute to the formation of the fruits.
True fruit: When the fruit develops from the ovary only, its is known as true fruit, such as- mango, berry, plum, pea etc.
In dillenia and apple the calyx and thalamus constitute fruits respectively.
Fruits are divided into three main classes on the basis of their origin and nature.
On the basis of the nature of pericarp, simple fruits are again classified into two groups, - dry fruits and fleshy fruits.
Dry fruits : Fruits having thinand dehiscent pericarps whenthey are ripe, are known as dry fruits.
Examples of such fruits are mustard, lady's finger etc.
Fleshy fruits : Fruits with thick and succulent pericarps are known as fleshy fruits.
The pericarp of fleshy fruit does not split open at maturity.
Mango, banana, apple, cucumbe etc belong to this group.
b) Aggregate fruit : When the fruit develops from the ovaries with many free carpels of a flower, it is known as aggregate fruit.
The number of fruitlets formed corresponds with the number of carpels present in the gynoecium of the flower.
Here a cluster of fruitlets is produced at a time.
A cluster of small fruits is known as an Etaerio.
Custard apple, lotus etc are examples of aggregate fruit.
Generally fertilization results in the formation of fruit.
But sometimes fruits may develop without fertilization.
Fruits have been classified into two groups on the basis of whether fertilization has occurred or not.
Natural fruit: The fruits which develop through the process of fertilization and have healthy seeds are regarded as natural fruits such.
Mango, jackfruit etc are natural fruits.
Parthenocarpic fruit: The fruits that develop without fertilization and contain immature seeds are known as parthenocarpic fruits.
Banana is an example of this type of fruit.
Fruits give protection to seeds.
Through seeds fruits give rise to new plants and thus helps the process of reproduction thereby maintaining the existence of plants.
Seeds : Most higher plants produce flowers.
Flowers develop fruits.
Fruits contain seeds.
Now a question may arise what is seed?
Seed is the fertilized mature form of ovule.
In most seeds the seed coat consists of two layers, such as- Outer layer:
The outermost layer of seed coat is hard and thick.
This is known as testa.
Inner layer: The innermost thin layer of seed coat is known as tegmen.
c) Multiple fruit : When all the flowers of an inflorescence together form a fruit, it is known as multiple fruit.
Here the fleshy sepals of the flowers of an inflorescence unite together to form a fruit.
A multiple fruit contains numerous seeds.
The axis which holds the cotyledons is known as embryonal axis.
The area of embryonal axis which is attached to the cotyledons is known as nodal zone.
The part of embryonal axis above the nodal zone is called epicotyl and the part below the nodal zone is known as hypocotyl.
The upper apex of the embryonal axis is known as plumule while the lower end of embryonalaxis is called radicle.
Plumule and radicle grow into shoot and root system respectively.
Cotyledons : The seed of a monocotyledonous plant bears a single cotyledon while that of a dicotyledonous plant contains two cotyledons.
Cotyledons that store food materials are thick and fleshy and those which do not store food are thin.
Cotyledons protect plumule; In non-endospermic seeds they store food for the embryo;
In endospermic seeds they absorb food materials from endosperm and supply it to the developing embryo;
In hypogeal type of germination they act as green leaves.
Endosperm : The tissue which stores food materials for the growing embryo is known as endosperm.
The stored food materials contain starch, protein, oil and fat.
Kernel : The material lying inside the seed coat is known as kernel.
Embryo: Embryo is the dormant minute plant covered by the seed coat.
Embryo consists of an embryonal axis and cotyledons.
Seeds have been grouped into two classes on the basis of the number of cotyledons.
Monocot seeds :Seeds having a single cotyledon are known as monocot seeds.
Paddy, wheat, maize etc are monocot seeds.
Dicot seeds: When a seed consists of two: cotyledons, it is termed as dicot seeds.
Examples of such seeds can be found in-gram, pea, bean, gourd, cucumber, mango etc.
Seeds have been divided again into two groups on the basis of the presence of endosperm.
Endospermic seeds: When food material are stored in the endosperm for future use, the seed is called endospermic seed.
In such seeds the cotyledons do not store food and, as a result, they become thin, such.
Seeds having no endosperm are known as nonendospermic seeds.
such asgram, gourd, pea, mango, bean etc. Cotyledons of such seeds become quite thick due to the storage of enough food materials.
Embryo, or baby plant remains dormant in a dry seed.
A dry seed seems to be an inert one.
But still then it bears viability within it.
At the dormant stage, growth remains ceased in the seed, but the required respiration goes on.
When necessary factors such as water, oxygen, temperature and light become available, the dormant embryo of the seed wakes up and begins to grow.
At one stage it penetrates the seed coat and comes out.
The process by which the embryo of a dormant seed starts growing is known as germination.
Germination of seeds is affected due to the absence of these factors.
Some seeds do not germinate in absence of light; such as-tobacco.
On the other hand, datura and tomato seeds do not require light at all for germination.
The necessity of required amount of water, oxygen and temperature in germination can be proved by the following experiment.
The piece of wood is placed in the beaker in a slanting position.
In such condition the beaker is to be kept for few days.
Observation: After three of four days, it will be observed that the first seed has not germinated at all.
The second seed has germinated normally while the third one has partial germination.
Inference: Since the first seed has got oxygen, temperature and light, but no water, it has not germinated.
The second seed has germinated normally because it has got the required amount of water, temperature, oxygen and light.
The partial germination of the third seed is due to the fact that it has got water and temperature but no oxygen.
There are three types of germination of seeds:
This type of germination takes place in mango, gram, pea, paddy, wheat etc.
Epigeal Germination: The process of germination is called epigeal when the cotyledons rupture seed coat and comes above the soil surface.
Examples: tamarind, bottle gourd, onion, gourd, bean etc.
Viviparous Germination: Plants which grow in saline soil of sea shores are known as halophyte.
Most plants or saline soil show a special type of germination called viviparous germination, such as-goran, keora, kakra etc.
The specialty of halophytic plants is that germination of seeds starts when the fruits are still attached with plants.
The radicle pierces through the fruit coat and remains suspended in air.
The hypocotyl becomes enlarged and swollen.
At this stage the plumule also grows in weight.
Due to the increase in weight, the daughter plant gets detached from the mother plant and falls of vertically fixing itself in the soft mud.
Because of viviparous germination seeds are not washed off by low and high tides in sea shore areas.
Without this process no vegetation could have been developed in sea shores.
In agriculture germination of seeds is very important.
Reduced rate of germination reduces yield of crops.
Before sowing, the rate of germination of seeds should be ascertained.
